We do not regard it as a Mickey Mouse proposal; we regard it as a serious, constructive and important new change in the world in terms of limiting the areas where nuclear proliferation can occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a Clayton's treaty.

—While Senator Chipp may interject that it is not a perfectly pure and pristine example of all the things he would want to embody in such a treaty, I make it quite clear that it is a decisive break from the past and a positive move to the future. Everyone in international fora has to work along those guidelines and not live in a land of idealism which is not achievable in the real world. Let me say that we distance ourselves from the Liberal Party, while identifying with the words in the motion moved by Senator Hill. We distance our position quite decisively from the position occupied by the Liberal Party in the past, although we welcome its new-found enthusiasm for this subject.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the Australian Democrats have seized on this opportunity, not to initiate a debate themselves-which is an option they had-but to amend the motion. Senator Gareth Evans, in putting the definite case for the Government, described our attitude to the Democrats' proposal. Perhaps a couple of aspects need to be enlarged on. Generally, we do not take exception to the terms of paragraph (a) of the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. However, we say that the best way of dealing with any proposal for a timetable is to attend the Geneva Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty Review Conference to expedite the negotiations on a comprehensive program of disarmament and to present that to the forty-first session of the United Nations General Assembly for adoption in 1986. That is a strategy that Australia has been internationally active in promoting. That seems to us to be the logical and proper course of action to take in respect of that proposal.

In reply to some of the assertions made by Senator Chipp, I am advised that no country has put forward a positive timetable for the NPT Review in terms of disarmament, although some countries did flirt with such a proposition. However, that has now been overtaken by other issues at the Review Conference such as the comprehensive test ban treaty issue, the question of chemical weapons and the question of radiological warfare. Broadly, we favour and are not too separate from the Australian Democrats in regard to paragraph (a). We support paragraph (b) of the motion.

However, in regard to paragraph (c) concerning the establishment of an energy for development fund, we have a number of points which I believe are important here. Of course, Article IV is a central core article of the Treaty. The Australian Government recognises and supports that. Also we recognise that Third World countries and the Group of 77 which have articulated their concern at previous review conferences about particular expressions by countries in regard to Article IV are concerned to generate and meet the energy needs to develop their economies to lift the standard of living of their peoples. That is a legitimate concern on their behalf. However, we recognise that conventional energy sources will be the main area in which those emerging countries will find their energy needs in the future. That does not mean to say we do not support funding and efforts to find alternative energy sources. We do support that. In fact, this Government, through Minister Evans's Department, is committed to such a program. However, we believe that there is no point in establishing yet another international body when a lot of work in this area has been done. Therefore, in the positive sense we do not support the commitment that the Australian Democrats would have us make in regard to paragraph (c).

Finally, in regard to paragraph (d) of Senator Chipp's amendment, we say that this Government has a lot to say and lot to be proud of in respect of how it has dealt with non-government organisations on the disarmament issue. After all it was this Government that created the post of Ambassador for Disarmament. It was, after all, this Government which instituted a division within the Department of Foreign Affairs to deal expressly with the question of disarmament and to provide regular and continual dialogue and contact with non-government organisations in Australia. That division of the Department of Foreign Affairs has been fostering that dialogue. I say on behalf of the non-government organisations themselves that one does not need to be pro-active as a government to encourage them to come forward. They are not shrinking violets. I do say that to condemn them; I say that to praise them. They are organisations with a keen idealism and a zealousness to put forward their point of view. They seek out governments; so that dialogue is a rich and widely flowing stream.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will not talk to them.

—Yes, we do. That is not true. We talk to them constantly. We talk to them constantly through the Department. In fact, this week at the Australian National University there is a seminar on this subject. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) himself has addressed it. The Department has an officer at the conference to present a paper and to engage in a continuing dialogue.
—He talks to them but he will not let them talk to him.
—Senator Chipp has said that we do not talk to non-government organisations.
—I am saying you will not let them talk to you.

—Yes, we do. We hear what they are saying. If the Democrats are saying that we have to adopt all the things that the organisations put to us to show that we have listened to them, that is preposterous. As two examples of the dialogue we have had in the recent past we have had direct contact with scientists against nuclear arms and lawyers for disarmament in New South Wales and Victoria. This Government will be conducting a debriefing round of discussions after the NPT review conference, as appropriate. The Government stands on its previous record of availability for discussions.

SPEECH.PARA: The last item of the Democrats' proposal is redundant. The words I now utter will never be gainsaid at any stage by proof of reluctance. I believe that there is no doubt that the Government will move directly and rapidly to overcome any blockage in the system of dialogue that is so necessary for this country to unite its voice in international fora on this issue.

I want to say a number of things about our concern as a party for nuclear disarmament because as the oldest political party in Australia the Australian Labor Party is the peace party by tradition. We have not discovered the issue recently. We have constantly been the party that has supplied people for most of the marches and demonstrations for peace over the years. It has been a major preoccupation of all our party conferences. It remains the most vibrant debate we ever have. To say that we are committed to the subject of peace is to be trite because the Labor Party by definition is known to stand four square in that field.

In fact ever since the Minister for Foreign Affairs became Minister in 1983 he has traipsed the world to promote the NPT, to encourage by personal diplomatic contact countries to sign the treaty to deal with those countries reluctant or difficult to convince to sign the treaty to do so and to pursue an orderly, rational strategy to make the treaty strong by making it more comprehensive with more countries becoming signatories. That is the first leg of our commitment.

As far as we are concerned, the Treaty is the vital cornerstone in the field of nuclear disarmament. Our strategy to make it an even stronger Treaty can best be described as having four prongs. The first is to hold the Treaty together. That is the vital precondition. The Treaty is under threat and it cannot be assumed automatically, simply because it is being reviewed, that it will continue. Some countries have raised serious criticisms of it, in our view justly, under section (6), Article VI. We too are not satisfied with the way in which the major super-powers have addressed the question of vertical proliferation. We also see the Treaty as a major opening for Australia, as a small to medium power in the world, to use its influence to bring about a tighter control over horizontal proliferation. So the first leg of our four-point strategy is to hold the Treaty together.

The second leg is to pursue a more comprehensive coverage of the Treaty, as I described it a moment ago, by bringing more nations within its ambit. It troubles us greatly that a number of nuclear weapons states remain uncommitted to the Treaty. A number of countries such as Argentina, Brazil, Pakistan, South Africa, Libya, and a number of other countries, which retain programs to develop nuclear weapons or have the capacity to develop nuclear weapons decline to sign the Treaty. One of our main efforts has been to encourage them to sign and to use all diplomatic methods to do so. With Spain especially we have mounted a major effort. It is pleasing to report that in the Pacific and the Association of South East Asian Nations area every country except Kiribati is a member of the Treaty. Many of them have joined recently.

Thirdly, our strategy is to hold all signatories to their Treaty commitments. Here, in particular, we will be joining those voices raised at the review conference to express concern and to bring pressure to bear for better results and a more fertile flowering of needs under Article VI. Fourthly, our key strategy is to strengthen the Treaty. So our strategy is to hold the Treaty together, push for complete coverage, hold signatories to their commitments and to strengthen and bolster the Treaty to make it a more effective device for nuclear disarmament.

I said that the key question for Australia is: How do we best use our influence in the world? There are various arguments. Some would say it should be done by symbolic gestures and others by supporting the arms race in the mutually assured destruction type of approach. We say that the best way of expressing our concern about disarmament is to work strenuously in all the fora available to bring pressure to bear to build block upon block for disarmament in the world.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Chipp

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. Senator Cook unwittingly misrepresented the Australian Democrats' point of view in saying that we had not taken the initiative on this question. I seek leave to make a statement, no longer than 30 seconds, to correct that.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The record will show that we have 11 items on the Notice Paper expressing our concern at nuclear proliferation, three of which specifically relate to the review conference next week. They were put there before today. The simple facts are that we do not have the numbers to bring them on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —For 20 years or so the world has had the capacity for self-destruction. We have perhaps got used to living in the atmosphere of such a possibility but is it extremely disturbing and deserves the closest attention of the whole world community. I do not know whether the scientists are right in saying that there will be a nuclear winter, with the probable destruction of all flora and fauna on the earth, in the event of a nuclear exchange between the super-powers, but I do know that all previous estimates by nuclear physicists of the likely results of their weapons have been underestimated. We must assume that a war between the super-powers will result in the end of civilisation and possibly of life on earth.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the disturbing features about all the debate on nuclear war is that a lot of it is about things which are not in dispute. No sane person wants to consider the possibility of a winnable nuclear war. We must assume that a war between the super-powers will inevitably escalate into an all out nuclear exchange. The issue is this: if there is a war between the super-powers there will be no place on earth to hide. The suburb next to me, Richmond, has a large sign which says `Nuclear Free Zone'. I do not think that in the event of a war between the super-powers my prospects of escaping will be enhanced by moving a few hundred yards to Richmond-or to New Zealand. In the event of a nuclear war there will be no place on earth to hide. Therefore, our overriding objective must be to ensure that such a nuclear war does not take place. There is no such thing as a winnable nuclear war. No sane person wants a nuclear war.

Australia can make contributions to preventing such a war and we would be criminally irresponsible if we did not take the opportunities open to us to reduce the likelihood of such a war. That is why we contribute to deterrence with our communications facilities at North West Cape which have the capability of communicating with missile firing submarines in the Indian Ocean. These are second strike weapons. While on station they are invulnerable. By their existence and their enormous retaliatory power they are a tremendous deterrent to the possibility of a surprise nuclear strike on the United States of America. As for surveillance facilities, United States bases in central Australia can provide a warning of a surprise launch of Soviet missiles. This, too, is an enormous deterrent to the outbreak of such a war. Some people, the Australian Democrats among others, would have us throw them away and say that we will not have these bases. They would increase, unwittingly perhaps, the likelihood of the outbreak of nuclear war. In my view it would be totally irresponsible for Australia, while these nuclear weapons exist, not to do all we can to make their use less likely.

What we are discussing today in particular is the Treaty for the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. That is a matter of considerable importance, because the reconsideration of this Treaty is starting next week. It is important to remember that this Non-Proliferation Treaty does not deal merely with the proliferation of nuclear weapons in new countries; it deals with the level of nuclear armaments in the existing nuclear powers. It is a two-fronted attack on the problems of nuclear weapons.

I think it is worth summarising what the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty does, in fact, do. Under Article I the nuclear weapons states undertake not to transfer nuclear weapons to the control of another country or to assist a non-nuclear weapons state to acquire them. Certainly, as to the first part of that article, so far as I know there has been no transfer of nuclear weapons to the control of another country. Actions have been taken by some countries that would appear to assist non-nuclear weapons states to acquire nuclear weapons. This is the thing we must pursue and do all we can through diplomatic means to prevent. Article II says that non-nuclear weapons states undertake not to manufacture or otherwise acquire nuclear weapons or nuclear explosive devices. As far as I am aware, none of the signatories to the Non-Proliferation Treaty has attempted to acquire nuclear weapons. There are non-signatories-I will come to this point in a moment-which will be in a position soon to acquire nuclear weapons.

Article III of the Treaty requires non-nuclear weapons states to accept International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards on all nuclear activities in their territories for the purposes of verifying the terms of Article II. Each member country is to require IAEA safeguards on exports of nuclear items to non-nuclear weapons states which are not a party to the NPT. Personally, I do not like that second provision. I do not think countries that are signatories to the NPT should export any nuclear items to non-signatories to the NPT. I think that is the sort of pressure we must apply to try to bring people under the umbrella of the NPT, to encourage them to sign it.

Article IV affirms the rights of all countries to use nuclear energy for peaceful purposes and requires countries in a position to do so to contribute to the development of nuclear energy in member countries. This is partly being breached by Australia. We are not freely exporting uranium. The free and economic availability of uranium is important to prevent the misuse of uranium, particularly the necessity for re-cycling or fast breeder reactors which would much increase the danger of proliferation to new countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you export it to Iran?

—No. I am coming to that. The conditions under which we export uranium are very tight, much tighter than in most other countries. In particular, I would like to see the members of the NPT not accepting any uranium from countries that are not signatories to the NPT. The most obvious exporter of uranium which is not a signatory to the NPT is South Africa. I do not think any signatories to this Treaty, which is designed to prevent the misuse of uranium, should accept uranium exports from countries that do not abide by the requirements of the NPT. That is the sort of pressure that we can and should put on countries to join in this Treaty.

SPEECH.PARA: Article V of the Treaty says that each party undertakes to ensure that the potential benefits from peaceful applications of nuclear explosions are made available to non-nuclear signatories on a non-discriminatory basis. The charge should be as low as possible and exclude research costs. Article VI is the one about which there is the most controversy. Under that article all parties to the Treaty undertake to work for a cessation of the nuclear arms race, for nuclear disarmament and ultimately for general and complete disarmament. There is no question that since the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty was negotiated 15 years ago the level of nuclear armaments under the super powers has risen quite sharply. This is a very disturbing trend. Our power influence it is relatively small, but there is one thing that we can and must do. It is quite inconceivable that an open society like the United States of America could enter into a treaty with the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, which is a closed society, unless it was sure that there was some verification that agreement reached with the USSR would be enforced. If America were to breach such a treaty, something would fall off the back of a truck very fast and it would be widely known that the Americans were not adhering to the treaty. That is not so in the case of a closed society such as the USSR.

We can contribute to influencing this trend because, through the surveillance facilities of satellites monitored by the stations in central Australia, we can monitor the testing of new weapons, the trial flights of new missiles. This is a very great contribution to making it possible for the United States to enter into meaningful bilateral negotiations for arms reduction. I think that, as with the other contributions we make, it would be irresponsible of us not to make this contribution, to think that in some way we can opt out of the world, and that not to set an example like this would, in some way which I have never understood, result in universal nuclear disarmament.

But the real problem of the Non-Proliferation Treaty concerns the people who are not signatories. There are 122 signatories at the moment and 45 countries are not signatories to the NPT. Notable among the countries that are not signatories are France and China, both nuclear weapons states, though France has indicated that it will behave as do the NPT signatories. The non-signatories include six countries with well-developed nuclear programs. These countries are Argentina, Brazil, India, Israel, Pakistan and South Africa.

It must be our great purpose to bring these countries within the terms of the Non-Proliferation Treaty. I have suggested two ways in which pressure can be exerted on them-that countries should not accept uranium exports from countries that are not signatories the NPT and that Article III should be amended so that nuclear items are not exported to countries that are not signatories to the NPT. These are steps that can be made to try to make it more desirable for countries that are now signatories to the NPT to become so. But our leverage is relatively small. Our main contribution at the moment to dealing with this horrifying situation, the possibility of the destruction of life on earth, is to aid the deterrent, to make it less likely that this nuclear arsenal will be used and also to provide facilities so that the United States can honestly enter into negotiations to reduce the level of its nuclear arms by our providing the verification that any such treaty is being adhered to by the Soviet Union.

Finally, by making our uranium available at a fair price on the world market, we can make the development of peaceful energy possible without all the distorting effects that artificial restrictions on the availability of uranium for peaceful purposes would cause. These would be very damaging to the cause of non-proliferation. We can make a substantial contribution to the prevention of a nuclear war, to making disarmament possible and to making the peaceful use of nuclear energy safe. These are contributions that we must make, and to fail to do so would be an act of criminal irresponsibility.

I am sorry that Senator Chipp has left the chamber. He said that he could not get the numbers in this chamber to have his Bills debated. As a matter of fact, the Australian Democrats declined to take the General Business time available to them today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite our reservations-or, more correctly, because of them-about the efficacy of the International Atomic Energy Agency, we who have been most critical of Australia's role in the international nuclear fuel cycle must support this urgency motion which seeks a strong and positive role for Australia in the forthcoming third review conference in Geneva of the members of the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. In 1976 the Fox report detailed the weaknesses of the Treaty and the IAEA, and there is no need to rehearse those deficiencies during this debate. Although international fora are rarely able to report progress of any great magnitude in the short term, my limited experience of United Nations negotiations has convinced me that we should treasure and nurture even the smallest steps towards better understanding between nations, greater recognition of the human rights of individuals, and wider sensitivity of the vulnerability of planet Earth to the past and potential onslaughts of technological and scientific discoveries.

SPEECH.PARA: Generally speaking, an immense amount of effort at the United Nations is expended on holding on to hard-won agreements and fighting off forces actively bent on regression, as Senator Cook has so eloquently explained. To those who take a cynical view of the United Nations and its agencies, I strongly recommend Dr Keith Suter's book Alternatives to War: the Peaceful Settlement of International Disputes, which was published in 1981 by the Women's International League for Peace and Freedom. This is an explanation of our only international arbitration system, as poorly understood, I believe, as our industrial arbitration system but similarly defusing potential conflicts, with little fuss and fanfare. Another publication of great value is The Forgotten Treaties by Allan McKnight, which details United Nations disarmament treaties. It is not a startling success story, but an indication again of the persistence and doggedness without which nothing can be achieved internationally.

Suggesting a role for the International Atomic Energy Agency, Allan McKnight refers to the need for an international disarmament treaty, the protocol of which he suggests in his publication. As he explains, the non-proliferation treaty is concerned with two forms of proliferation, horizontal and vertical. The NPT has been successful on the well-publicised former type of proliferation, but the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the United States of America have failed to keep their end of the agreement, 15 years after concluding it. Additionally, accounts by officials closely connected with arms control negotiations, show just how much effort the negotiations consumed, and for so little achievement. Twenty years after the completion of the partial test ban treaty, for example, the USSR and the United Kingdom have still failed to conclude a test ban treaty including a ban on underground tests. It could be said that in disarmament terms never before have so many worked so long and achieved so little. The alternative, however, is unthinkable. In 1981, at which time there were 115 signatories to the NPT, the Secretary-General of the United Nations said:

Progress towards promoting the universality of that Treaty and the generalised acceptance of International Atomic Energy safeguards would go far to allay anxieties that the spread of nuclear technology and material might open the door to potential military capabilities. It is also important to give urgent consideration to ways of ensuring that advanced technological means will not be used to circumvent the safeguards system.

He drew attention to the growing consideration of nuclear weapons-free zones and cited the new-at that time-Treaty of Tlatelolco. He referred to these as significant measures of non-proliferation and regional nuclear disarmament. The recently developed treaty on a nuclear-free South Pacific agreed to by Australia is an outstanding example of a valuable step in that direction, limited by national aspirations in some cases and by some overriding conventions, such as the Law of the Sea, but in the long term highly significant. Why else would it have engendered such violent opposition?

International Atomic Energy safeguards must obviously provide the maximum possible confidence and the removal of at least some of the sources of mistrust and hostility between nations. Given the opportunity Australia must, and I have every reason to believe will, exert every effort to strengthen the safeguards. This is not only because of their inherent weakness otherwise in preventing horizontal proliferation, but also to help promote the climate in which negotiations on strategic arms limitation can proceed and prosper. To quote again from the Secretary-General of the United Nations:

The maintenance of dialogue is an essential part of the effort to remove the causes of suspicion and hostility . . . It must be recognised that the search for absolute security can, in fact, breed further insecurity. History demonstrates that there are times when an arms race can acquire a mementum of its own, quite independent of the political causes which initially provoked it, and lead inexorably to disaster.

As the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) said earlier in this debate, there are now 130 signatories to the NPT, an update on the figures given by Senator Hamer. These include all the ASEAN nations in the South Pacific Forum and the South Pacific Forum countries, with the exception of Vanuatu. The Minister in this debate also emphasised that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has, without prompting from the Opposition, raised the question of the NPT with non-signatories including India, Pakistan, Israel, Spain and Argentina.
It is the duty of the international community, in the words of the Secretary-General of the United Nations:

. . . to attempt to break, at every possible point, the deadly cycle which leads from suspicion and hostility to increased armaments and from increased armaments to a further heightening of suspicion and hostility. At the same time, a renewed and concerted effort by the international community, conducted at every level, including the very highest, to deal directly with the threats posed by the arms race in all its forms seems to me in order.

It seems that way to the Australian Government. Senator Chipp's proposal for an Energy for Development Fund is not an objectionable suggestion, but is hardly necessary in view of the fact that there are already a range of United Nations activities geared towards development and alternative sources of energy and Australia, so far as I am aware, is a donor to each of these funds. Some years ago the United Nations completed a study of the question of the economic consequences of the arms race-a question not unrelated to that of the development and promotion of renewable energy sources. The report was adopted without vote by the General Assembly on 9 December 1981. Since then France has taken the disarmament and development exercise further by proposing an international fund for development.

A resolution was adopted at the last General Assembly in December 1984 providing for a conference on disarmament and development to be held, and for a preparatory committee to be established to recommend a provisional agenda, procedure, place, date and duration of such a conference. Australia attended the first meeting of the preparatory committee, which took place in New York between 29 July and 6 August this year. Australia agrees that a major conference such as that proposed by France could go a long way towards examination of the relationship between disarmament and development, and therefore supports the holding of a well-prepared conference on this subject. We have serious reservations about the establishment of a fund at this stage. In the absence of meaningful disarmament, a disarmament fund for development would either be empty or consist of moneys that would have been devoted to development assistance in any case, but through one of the existing mechanisms.

At the recent world conference in Nairobi on the end of the United Nations Decade for Women, a recurrent theme was the necessity for women to participate fully in all aspects of the formulation of monitoring, review and appraisal of national and international policy issues and activities. One of the many contributions made to the Nairobi conference by Australia was a resolution calling for all nations to include women on their delegations to all United Nations conferences concerned with peace and disarmament. We made this move from a position of some strength, the disarmament delegate on our delegation being Tonia Shand, First Assistant Secretary in the disarmament section of the Department of Foreign Affairs. She and other officers of the Department are constantly in touch with non-governmental organisations, among which there are forceful and effective women's organisations whose contributions we value and solicit. Those non-governmental organisations with observer status at the United Nations-those that are genuinely international organisations-are invariably represented by their permanent delegates in New York and in Geneva.

Senator Chipp's reference to pathetic reliance on the Non-Proliferation Treaty might be correct if it were not for the fact that this is only one of the many initiatives of the Australian Government in the crucial sphere of disarmament. There is no argument with supporting and strengthening all such attempts to ensure a secure world for us, our children and our children's children. Australia goes to the forthcoming conference determined to do the best that it possibly can do to avoid the farce feared by Senator Chipp, taking the constructive and positive approach that has characterised the current Australian Government's role in international affairs.
Motion (by Senator Kilgariff) agreed to:
That the question be now put.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Sitting suspended from 6.22 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The two-volume report entitled `Future Directions for Commercial Television' produced by the Forward Development Unit of the Department of Communications represents one of the most significant reports in the communications area to come before the Parliament and, indeed, to potentially shape the broadcasting sector in Australia. The report deals with a series of significant policy determinations to be made by this Government as far as the future development of commercial television in Australia is concerned, particularly given the impact of the domestic satellite which is to be launched on Saturday and which hopefully will usher in an entirely new era in broadcasting in Australia.

The report identifies two basic approaches to the question of equalisation. The Government has made equalisation the prime goal of its communications policy. In a statement issued on 30 April, Mr Duffy, the Minister for Communications, indicated that the equalisation of services is the most significant long term goal which this Government has in mind. The report of the Forward Development Unit of the Department of Communications indicated that there were two approaches that could be taken. It describes the first approach as aggregation, which essentially is to allow a linking of the broadcast areas of particular commercial television stations. The second, which it calls approach B, involves multi-channel services-that is to say, to allow an existing broadcaster to provide three services, or certainly that sort of number of services, within the area in which he already has a monopoly position. The report comes down very clearly in favour of the process of aggregation-that is to say, to aggregate existing television markets with their different ownerships in order to create markets which are big enough to support three competitive television services, thereby equalising for non-metropolitan Australia the services which are available to metropolitan viewers.

An important number of considerations arise from this. The first and most important is that a process of equalisation on the basis of aggregation means the death knell for the philosophy of localism in television broadcasting. The enthusiastic adoption of the recommendations of the Oswin report a couple of years ago, which dealt with the preservation of localism in broadcasting, will have to be set to one side if the process of equalisation by aggregation continues. Equalisation by aggregation will mean the development of local super networks. In my view, the economics of regional networking are such-I think this is clearly shown in the two reports themselves-that there seems to be no doubt it will only be a prelude to the introduction of a system of national networking whereby the principal networks already existing in Australia, which are at the moment confined primarily to the metropolitan areas, will be allowed to extend their influence into the non-metropolitan areas. In fact, the Government has now clearly signalled its approval of the fact that Australian commercial television will inevitably become a system of national networking.

Time does not permit me to indicate the extent to which the whole philosophy of supplementary licences has now collapsed with these changes in new broadcasting technology. The workload of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, which has been allocated only an extra $160,000 in this year's Budget to discharge all of its additional responsibilities, is such that it is heading for a situation in which it will be unable to control, monitor and to direct television services in Australia in the way in which it has in the past and as its set requires. The adoption of the aggregation recommendations of this very significant report, together with the Government's commitment to the philosophy of equalisation of television services, means that this country is now headed in the direction of super-networking and thence national networking as far as commercial television in Australia is concerned. That will require some very sensitive policy adjustments by any government and some very sensitive supervision of those policy and legislative initiatives by this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to agree with Senator Puplick on this matter. I think it is extremely important to realise that we are moving towards a situation of total dominance of our media by networks. The Forward Development Unit of the Departments of Communications has presented a report which is moving us definitely in this direction. The Forward Development Unit was supposed to concentrate on two time frames when it was set up by the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) in February-the medium term future, which was 1988 to 1997, and the long term future, from 1997 onwards. In May the Minister issued a Press release indicating that the way was now open for three commercial television services to operate in regional Australia. Extra resources were to be made available to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and to the Department of Communications in order to assist the acceleration of new services. It was the Government's hope that the majority of regional areas would have three commercial television services in three years time. This is another example of Hawke trilogies. This particular trilogy was to come about before 1990. The buzz words at that stage were `equalisation' and `as soon as possible'. As a result, the Forward Development Unit looked only at the short term options and this has been a disaster.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to recognise that vast developments are taking place in the area of communications. One example of this is optical fibre technology. Australian researchers are difinitely in the forefront in this area. Optical fibre technology will make it possible to obtain greater diversity of programming in metropolitan and near regional areas. Cable subscription services and public television will be readily possible. Innovative programming options such as those used by Britain's Independent Broadcasting Authority should not be ruled out because of a lack of infrastructure and broadcasting facilities. I believe that while Telecom Australia is putting in new fibre optic cables it should be required to install broad-band cables capable of diversified television transmission. I note that the European Commission has a research and development program that it hopes will create by 1992 an integrated wide band communications network. This will replace the radio frequency type of network. Glass and optical fibre links which transmit voice and image at the speed of light will replace copper wires. We must be careful to look far enough ahead to ensure proper planning. A satellite is about to go up and fundamental decissions are only just at the public discussion stage.

At page 22 of the Forward Development Unit's report it is suggested that it may eventually prove to be necessary to treat the supplementary licence approach as an interim step towards aggregation. Senator Puplick covered this area quite effectively. There is also the question of the way in which supplementary licences are granted and the opportunities, if any, for independent licensees to enter the field. Some of the statements contained in the current report, I feel, will make this more and more difficult. A striking feature of the report is the absence of detailed work on the impact that various options can be expected to have on the quality of Australian programming. This is already happening with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I believe that in the current situation more effort must be placed on examining what we will do in the medium and distant future.
