TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Social Welfare, I present a report dated June 1985 on children in institutional and other forms of care, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I have the honour to present to the Senate the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare entitled `Children in Institutional and Other Forms of Care-A National Perspective'. The Committee's report represents the culmination of an extensive inquiry into the circumstances and needs of children who, for a variety of reasons, are removed from their family homes-either by their parents acting voluntarily in a private capacity, or by the State acting in accordance with certain statutory provisions-and are placed in alternative or substitute forms of parental care.

The types of substitute care examined by the Committee included the practice of adoption, short term and long term foster care, institutional or residential care, care provided by a child's relatives or friends, and care provided through community-based refuges.

The Committee has estimated that over 30,000 children are in substitute care in Australia today. This represents a welcome decline over the past decade in the overall number of children in the traditional categories of care, such as adoption, foster care and institutional care. However, this estimate does not take account of the fact that there has been an increase in the number of children requiring substitute care in youth refuges-a matter of considerable concern to the Committee. It is also significant that two groups of children continue to be over represented in care-Aboriginal children and children with disabilities.

The declining trend in the overall number of children in substitute care also tends to disguise other problems facing those children remaining in substitute care: First, that too many children continue to spend too long in care; secondly, that such children are subjected to too many changes in care arrangements; thirdly, that they are too readily discharged and re-admitted to care; and, fourthly, that they have too little contact with their parents while in care.

Many of these criticisms are symptomatic of deficiencies in policies and practices that limit the effectiveness of the present substitute care system. Problems highlighted during the inquiry included: The lack of adequate government funding, particularly for the non-government sector which bears a disproportionate share of the burden of providing substitute care services; the lack of evaluation of programs and services; the inadequacy of statistical collections in this area; the poor standard of care provided by some agencies and the lack of appropriate training for substitute care personnel; the insufficient educational support available for children in residential institutions; the absence of proper assessment and planning procedures for the placement of children in care by some welfare organisations; and the minimal exchange of information and ideas between welfare agencies and between the States on recent developments and changes in substitute care policy and practice.

In an attempt to overcome these shortcomings the Committee has made a series of recommendations relating to each of these matters. In particular, it has recommended that the Commonwealth Government introduce a uniform and increased foster parents' allowance; promote improvements in the quality of substitute care by supporting the development of pre-service and in-service training for both government and non-government substitute care personnel; introduce a special substitute care grants program to assist government and non-government welfare agencies in the implementation of proper assessment and planning procedures for the placement of children in substitute care; promote the evaluation of substitute care services by assisting State and Territory government and non-government welfare departments and agencies to determine appropriate evaluation criteria and develop procedures for the establishment and maintenance of ongoing evaluation programs; and improve educational programs for children resident in institutions by firstly providing greater encouragement and assistance to enable them to participate in education or training-at least until they have completed a full secondary education or its equivalent-and secondly by preparing and equipping older children leaving residential care with independent living skills.

As part of the inquiry, the Committee investigated the reasons why children are placed in substitute care and examined the effectiveness of present public policies and programs aimed at preventing or avoiding the need to remove children from their home evironment and place them in care. In evidence received by the Committee, the three most frequently mentioned reasons for the placement of children in substitute care were firstly, parental and family conflict or breakdown; secondly, concern for the child's welfare, for example, because of parental neglect, child abuse et cetera; and thirdly the inability of parents to cope with the demands of family life.

The Committee found that these factors are invariably linked to a family's immediate economic and social circumstances. Today, as in the past, the families of children in substitute care are still predominantly the poorest, the most disadvantaged and the most vulnerable. The Committee concluded that, as children are placed in substitute care primarily because their families are unable to provide adequately for them, the provision of substitute care services must be viewed in the broadest preventive context. This in turn means that public policy must address more rigorously such problems as unemployment, income maintenance, the provision of adequate housing and the capacity of the education system to equip all members of the community with the necessary skills and knowlege to cope with the demands of adult family life. It also means that effective and accessible community-based family support services must be available where children are at risk of of being removed from their families and placed in substitute care. In this respect, the Committee welcomes the development in the States and Territories of recent child and family welfare policies that reflect a growing emphasis on the need for preventive programs. However, it is a matter for concern that despite these changes in public policy, for the most part resources continue to be channelled towards providing stop-gap measures to families in crisis.

Because the demands for assistance by families in immediate need must necessarily take priority in the planning and delivery of state welfare programs, the Committee considers it is unrealistic to expect State governments to assume sole responsibility for the development of longer term preventive strategies. It therefore believes that the Commonwealth, through such programs as the family support services scheme, should play a greater role in this area. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that the family support services scheme be continued and expanded by the Commonwealth Government.

Finally, in bringing together the findings of the inquiry, the Committee considers that the most serious problem facing governments and others in the development and implementation of Commonwealth and State government and non-government welfare policies and programs for families and children, including those aimed at improving the type and quality of substitute care services, concerns the lack of co-ordination in this area at the national level. Closely allied with this problem is the fact that despite the Commonwealth's increasing involvement in child and family welfare matters, particularly through the children's services program, the Commonwealth has failed to make any clear statement of national policy regarding its role and responsibility vis-a-vis the States and Territories in the long term planning and provision of child and family welfare services. As a result, the delivery of such services in this country continues to be beleaguered by confusion, fragmentation, duplication, and inefficient and inequitable use of resources.

In an attempt to rectify this situation, the Committee has recommended that the Commonwealth Government introduce legislation providing for the establishment of a national statutory authority to be known as the Australian Children and Families Commission to advise the Government on matters of policy concerning the development of welfare programs for children and families and to develop strategies to improve the overall planning and co-ordination of such programs. In making this recommendation the Committee has stressed that it is not intended that the Commonwealth assume direct responsibility for the delivery and administration of community services for children and families. Rather, the proposal recognises the need to address child and family welfare problems at the national level and to ensure that, through consultation and co-operation with the States and Territories, the future provision of services through the present multiplicity of Commonwealth, State and Territory government departments and non-government welfare agencies is achieved in a more planned and co-ordinated manner across Australia. In this sense, the body would be similiar in purpose to the proposed National Children's Commission for which legislation was passed in 1975 but which was never established. Further aspects of this proposal, particularly the reasons why the Committee does not believe the functions of this national body can be carried out by an existing Commonwealth department, will be discussed by my colleague, Senator Giles, in her speech to the Senate during the debate on the Committee's report.

Before concluding my remarks, I would like to record, on behalf of the Committee, my appreciation of the co-operation and assistance provided by all witnesses who gave evidence at the Committee's public hearings and by others who contributed to the inquiry through written submissions. During the inquiry the Committee received over 150 submissions and heard evidence from more than 100 groups and individuals. One aspect of the inquiry that was of particular value to the Committee was the series of visits the Committee made to the States where it held informal discussions with many people, including children in substitute care, their parents, foster care agencies and foster parents, and institutional care personnel. I know my colleagues on the Committee would wish me to express our appreciation of the constructive and forthright approach taken by these groups towards the inquiry.

At this stage I would like to thank all honourable senators who worked on the Committee. It was very enlightening work and I am certain that all honourable senator's hearts were touched in the course of this inquiry when listening to the many tragic experiences of people. Finally, I thank the Committee secretariat for its support and guidance during the inquiry. Mrs Doreen Russell, the Committee steno-secretary, gave magnificent support to the Comittee. I thank her very much for all the work she has done. I thank the Committee's two research officers, Mr Peter Hallahan and Mr Peter Short, who both provided magnificent help and who worked for very long hours. Both are very worthy of the Commite's commendation.

I would also like to thank Monica Darmody for her valuable work. She was attached to the Committee for three months. I would also like to thank a former research officer, Miss Pam Gulloni, who now resides in Italy. I am certain that all members of the Committee would thank her very much for her very dedicated work and her great love of children. Finally, I consider that our Committee Secretary, Mr Chris Shrosbree, is one of the finest secretaries in the Senate standing committee system. He works unceasingly. If it were not for people like Chris Shrosbree the Senate committees would be unable to function correctly. On behalf of the Committee, I thank him and all members of the research staff. All that remains is for me to commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I would like to congratulate Senator Elstob on his chairmanship of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare because he carried out his duties in that position in a most appropriate and unbiased manner. I enjoyed working under his chairmanship. During the homeless youth inquiry the Committee was concerned at the ages of some of the children who ended up in refuges. We were told by some of the police who were giving evidence that it was now considered inappropriate to put young girls into institutional care. Instead, they took them to refuges. We were told that 27 per cent of children in refuges were aged between 12 and 15 years.

SPEECH.PARA: I assure honourable senators that refuges are not appropriate places for children of that age to be sheltered. We were also concerned during the inquiry that such a large number of them had spent time in institutional care. We were told that 12 per cent had previously resided in residential or foster care. The fact that they turned up as homeless youth in refuges was most unfortunate. We sought terms of reference that would give us the opportunity to inquire into the whole area. The reasons for placement of children in other forms of care were, as Senator Elstob said, very similar to those in the homeless youth area-parental and family conflict, family breakdown or concern for the child's welfare because of parental neglect or child abuse. There were many reasons. There was an unwillingness or, in some situations, an inability by parents to accept the responsibility of bringing up their children in a responsible fashion.

Since 1940 there has been a slow movement away from institutional care and an emphasis on keeping children with the parents whenever it was at all posssible. There has also been a move away from big institutions towards smaller institutions. We saw many children in small cottage care instead of in the larger institutions that had been so prominent in years gone by. We were told that this was a very good move and that it was essential to keep children with their parents. Some people gave evidence that children should be with their parents at all costs. It was only as a very last resort that they should be taken away from their parents. I will elaborate on that in a few minutes.

We were told that there was a decline in the number of children entering institutional care. Data compiled by the Australian Bureau of Statistics revealed that in 1984 at least 30,309 children were living in some form of substitute care.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did that include adoptees?

—Yes. Other figures given to us by the Bureau of Statistics-I point this out to Senator Baume-the Department of Social Security and State welfare departments showed that the overall number of children available for adoption or placement in foster or institutional care had fallen from approximately 39,600 in 1972 to 22,500 in 1984. Similarly, the number of children under State guardianship in 1972 was 26,846-an estimated rate of 5.9 per thousand of population under 18 years of age-compared with 22,661 in 1979, or 5.1 per thousand. That figure had fallen by 1982 to 3.6 per thousand. We were told that there were various reasons for this. One was the fall in the fertility rate, but the main reason was that there was a movement away from putting children in care. There was a definite attitude that a child should stay with its parents at all costs.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1982 the Victorian Department of Community Welfare Services stated that children requiring residential placement in 1980 appeared to be more in need of intensive care and treatment than the residential care population 10 years ago. This concern was expressed to us on many occasions by various groups looking after children. They said that it is all very well to say that children should remain with their parents at all costs but that they were now finding that greater numbers of children coming into care needed more intensive care. They had great behavioural problems. It was even suggested that we were just putting off the evil hour; that we were not putting them into care early enough; and that as time went by we would find more and more problems. The Committee stated in its report:

The Committee believes they highlight the dangers inherent in policies that underestimate the role of substitute care and early childhood intervention, and place undue emphasis on the maintenance of the child within its natural family or promote the early and, at times, premature restoration of children to their families.

Foster care parents have told us the same thing-that the children are perfectly happy while they are with the foster parents and seem to improve. Suddenly, the parents want them back. They are restored to the foster parents at some later time when further and greater problems are exacerbated.

We were also well aware that while the numbers of children in institutional care were coming down the numbers of homeless youth appeared to be increasing. Between October 1980 and September 1981 there were over 12,000 requests for emergency accommodation at refuges funded under the refuge scheme. But the estimate was that the figure was more like 15,000. It was suggested that perhaps many of the children could have been successfully fostered or placed in some form of institutional care rather than roaming from shelter to shelter. As I said earlier, shelters are not appropriate places for young children 12, 13 or 14-year-olds.

As Senator Elstob has said, the Committee was also very concerned that Aboriginal children were over-represented in all the States we visited. In Western Australia, for instance, Aboriginal children represent 54 per cent of children in foster care and 57 per cent of children in residential care, although the Aboriginal people constitute only 2.4 per cent of the population of that State. So there is a great over-representation. In taking evidence from the Aboriginal people in charge of the Aboriginal child care agencies we were told that historically it was usual for children to be taken away from Aboriginal people and given to white foster parents. They objected very strongly to this having occurred. However, since the mid-1970s, Aboriginal based child care agencies have been set up. They must now be approached before an Aboriginal child is fostered in any way. While in the majority of cases they are able to make sure that these children are put with Aboriginal families, not enough Aboriginal families are available or willing to come forward so, unfortunately, in certain situations Aboriginal children still have to be put with white families. Despite all the efforts that have been made since the early 1970s, Aboriginal children in care are still at this stage over-represented in all the States.

The one area that I found most rewarding was that of the foster care parents, for whom I formed a tremendous admiration. They are a magnificent group of women and men who look after these children-sometimes they are problem children, sometimes they are just children who have been deserted. They look after them, bring them up with their own children and are usually well out of pocket through doing so. They have the biggest hearts, I think, of any people in our community. Our report commends them very highly. It says:

In all the States it visited, the Committee was impressed by the commitment of foster parents to the children for whom they were responsible and the considerable personal sacrifices willingly made by them in fulfilling their role. In every case, their prime concern for both the immediate and future well-being of the children placed in their care, whether on a short-term or long-term basis, was evident. The Committee strongly believes foster care provides an essential form of substitute care for many children and, when compared with the cost of alternative forms of care, such as institutional care, is a highly cost-effective substitute care arrangement.

It certainly is cost effective because foster care parents pay out of their own pockets on so many occasions for the children for whom they are caring. Our Committee recommended the upgrading of finance for this group of parents. But I found it most interesting that some of the foster care parents said to us: `Well, don't put it up too much. If you do, if you make it a financial incentive, you will destroy the true love, care and affection that must be there when fostering children.'

There was only one area in which several of us found that there was a need for a minority report. Senator Bjelke-Petersen, Senator Messner, Senator Sheil, and I joined in a minority report because the committee, as Senator Elstob has said, recommended that a commission be set up to co-ordinate and advise the Government in this area. We believe that there is no need to set up separate bureaucracy, another commission. We believe that the Office of Child Care and the Institute of Family Studies could certainly take on this extra role and that it is essential for plain government control that we should not set up yet another bureaucracy, another commission.

I believe that this has been a very happy Committee. I have very much enjoyed serving under Senator Elstob's chairmanship and I join him in his praise of the staff. We have been very fortunate in our staff. They have worked very well. Again, I join Senator Elstob in his praise of Mr Shrosbree. Honourable senators may or may not be aware that the Committee was in a very difficult position because it had two terms of reference at the same time. Mr Shrosbree took on the other reference and ended up doing so much on the children in institutional and other forms of care reference that he was virtually running two committees at once. It was all done so cheerfully and competently that I congratulate him on his secretaryship of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity of contributing to this debate on the tabling of the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare entitled `Children in Institutional and Other Forms of Care-a National Perspective'. I am particularly gratified that Senator Walters has had the opportunity to comment on this report. We have spent very many hours together on this reference and it is altogether fitting that she should contribute her impressions of the Committee's conclusions. I wish to highlight a number of the Committee's findings and then, as foreshadowed by Senator Elstob, discuss what the Committee found to be the most serious problem affecting the present and future development and implementation of Commonwealth and State welfare policies and programs, including those designed to improve the quality of life of children in institutional and other forms of care. Our greatest concern has been the lack of a co-ordinated approach in this country towards the planning, delivery and evaluation of community services that will promote the well-being of children and enhance the stability of families.

SPEECH.PARA: As part of its inquiry, the Committee examined the provision of substitute care services, particularly the practices of adoption, foster care and institutional care. With regard to adoption, three major issues were brought to the Committee's attention: The inadequacy of present inter-country adoption procedures; the implications of adoption for ethnic minorities, especially Aboriginal children; and the right of access to original birth records and personal documents by adopted persons. Most witnesses who commented on these matters were critical of the differences between the States in adoption laws and practices. The Committee agrees that such variations are unsatisfactory and has urged both government and non-government welfare agencies to seek greater uniformity in official adoptive policies and regulations throughout Australia.

The Committee found that foster care provides an appropriate form of substitute care for many children and, when compared with the cost of alternative forms of care such as institutionalisation, is highly cost effective. The Committee also considers that fostering has wider potential application than present policies and practices in most States would indicate. In this respect, it applauds the initiatives taken in South Australia through the development of the intensive neighbourhood care scheme which selects and trains foster parents to care for young offenders who would otherwise be committed to juvenile corrective institutions.

Two matters of special concern in this area were: Firstly, the variation in the value of foster care allowances between the States, notwithstanding differences in the cost of living; and, secondly, the overall inadequacy of the level of allowances. As at October last year, the base rate of the foster care allowance fell between the range of $30 and $55 a week depending on the age of the child and the State or Territory in which the child lived. Research by such organisations as the Children's Welfare Association of Victoria and the Institute of Family Studies has shown that in 1981-82 the cost of maintaining a child was $41 per week for primary school age children and $66 per week, which is $80 in 1985 prices, for teenage children.

Other evidence received by the Committee not only supports these findings but also shows that it is not uncommon for foster parents to be out of pocket through meeting the expenses of children in their care. Since the completion of the inquiry I have had an indication that the cost of repairs and replacement is also high for foster parents, bearing in mind that severely disturbed children can be very destructive. The Committee regards this as an untenable arrangement and considers that the value of foster parent allowances should reflect more accurately the real and increasing costs involved in providing proper care for a fostered child. In this respect the Committee has made a number of recommendations concerning the introduction of uniform and increased national foster parents allowances.

With regard to institutional care, this form of substitute care has long been the subject of criticism by those concerned with child care theory and practice. Much has been said and written about the disadvantages of institutional care and the detrimental effects it can have on the emotional, cognitive and social development of children. Conversely, it has also been demonstrated that, for some children, a good institution may be a more satisfactory environment for a child's growth and development than a poor home. Whether institutional care per se has a beneficial or harmful effect on children is therefore debatable. Recent reforms in both protective and corrective institutional care, such as the movement towards de-institutionalisation and the development of family group homes, have attempted with some success to redress negative aspects of this form of care. Overall, the Committee found that institutional care plays an important role in providing a form of substitute care for children with special needs, and may often be the best and most appropriate type of care for certain children at a particular point in time. In the Committee's view, institutional care is, and should continue to be, an appropriate alternative method of substitute care. It is, however, necessary to recognise the distinctiveness of its role within the wider spectrum of child care and community services and to ensure that it does not, as in the past, constitute the only choice because of the unavailability of alternative forms of care or the absence of adequate community-based family support services.

With regard to the provision of family support services, it became apparent to the Committee that there is a growing demand within the community for a wider range of such services than is presently available. In particular, local agencies and neighbourhood groups identified the need for more resources to be directed towards preventive welfare programs, such as those provided through the family support services scheme, including parent education courses, pre-marital and family counselling services, respite care services for families under stress, child abuse prevention programs, and homemaker services, which I believe are among the most cost-effective of all the forms of assistance that can be given to families at risk. In the report the Committee has argued that the Commonwealth should play a greater role in the development of such preventive services and has recommended that the family support services scheme should be continued and expanded.

During the inquiry it became evident to the Committee that the provision of child and family welfare services in this country, including the provision of programs and facilities for children requiring institutional and other forms of care, is an area in which there is little communication between the States and Territories and the Commonwealth, and that it is one in which service delivery is fragmented, lacking in design and cohesion, and leaving significant gaps in its coverage. At the local level, the Committee found that community services are often reactive, show little, if any, evidence of forward planning and tend to operate in isolation from other services. As a result the potential of many new initiatives in this area is not fully realised, especially in terms of their possible application in a wider context. Further, it is not possible to state with any degree of certainty whether financial resources now allocated, either by the Commonwealth or the States, are being used efficiently, effectively or equitably. The Committee believes many of these problems can be attributed, in part, to the fact that, despite its increasing involvement, especially through the provision of child care and family support services funded under the children's services program, the Commonwealth has failed to make any clear statement of national policy regarding its role and responsibility vis-a-vis the States and Territories in the long term planning and the delivery of community welfare services.

In the report the Committee noted that the Commonwealth has seen fit to legislate in the area of human rights through the Human Rights Commission, and in the area of family law through the Family Law Act 1976, which involves the regulation of family life as it relates to divorce and custody and maintenance of children. Action has been taken in these areas in response to certain changes within the community and in recognition of the need for a national approach. Similarly, the Committee believes that the Commonwealth should respond to other recent developments that have affected the welfare needs of the Australian community, and accept greater responsibility at the national level for ensuring that the overall framework within which public welfare policies and programs are devised is capable of both responding to changing social needs and facilitating a more rational approach towards the provision of welfare services.

The Committee has therefore recommended that the Commonwealth legislate for the establishment of a national body, to be known as the Australian Children and Families Commission, with responsibility first, for the development of policy and the provision of advice to the Commonwealth Government on matters affecting the well-being of children and the stability of families, and, secondly, for the promotion, through co-operation and consultation with the States and Territories, of a better planned and co-ordinated approach towards the delivery of community services throughout Australia. It is the Committee's view that a national body with this role should be independent of existing Commonwealth executive departments and thus be in a position to provide the government of the day with impartial advice on the welfare needs of children and families. During its deliberations on this matter the Committee questioned whether it would be preferable for the functions of this body to be carried out by an existing government department or agency, including the Department of Community Services. After long and serious consideration, the Committee concluded against this proposition. Its reasons for this decision are listed in the report, but they go very much to the question of independence of particular governments and of autonomy in making decisions that are appropriate and acceptable, not only to State government departments but also to the very wide non-government organisation network which is involved in the care of children.

The Committee envisages that as part of its function of promoting the stability of families the new body should be required to examine the means of maintaining the family entity as the fundamental group unit in society. This would involve the continuing review of the effect on family functioning. In this respect we use the term `family' to encompass households within which there are family relationships and not the narrower notion of a nuclear family. We include here the economic status of families in Federal and State legislation and family support programs.

With respect to the welfare of children, the new body would be required to develop a set of guiding principles to formalise national standards and goals for their well-being. It is envisaged that these would be based on the principles adopted in the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of the Child. As an ongoing function it would also have responsibility for assessing the needs of the Australian community for welfare services for children, particularly those whose needs may not be met through the development of policies and programs directed towards ensuring the stability of the family unit. Such special groups include children in institutional and other forms of substitute care, children who have offended against the law, homeless children, disabled children, migrant children, Aboriginal children and children who are victims of abuse. It may be useful in this regard to note that the Committee has interpreted `a child' as being one under the age of 18 years.

In carrying out this function, the new body would obtain a national overview of the adequacy of children's services and would be in a position to identify changing needs and gaps in service delivery. On the basis of such assessments, it would make recommendations to government concerning the need for special purpose programs that could be developed and implemented, either by the new body or by the most relevant Commonwealth department or authority, in consultation and co-operation with the States and Territories. We do not envisage just another commission. We envisage a body, probably quite small, which would carry out these functions and fulfill a crying need in the community in the way that the Schools Commission has demonstrated its utility. The proposed national body could also have the function of educating the community and acting as a public watchdog of government activity, for example, in relation to the effects on the family of government policy decisions concerning income maintenance, taxation, law reform, housing, education, health and employment. To assist the new body in its public watchdog role and other policy analysis, it is proposed that the Institute of Family Studies be subsumed as the national body's research arm.

Among the publications utilised by the Committee, research papers prepared by the Institute of Family Studies have proved to be of immense and unique value. Recent papers from the Institute of Family Studies include papers on the role of fathers in raising children, the problems of step-families, families and the taxation summit, family values of Australia's ethnic groups, a call for an improved level of child-family policy debate in Australia, the cost of children and divorce property law. These are all very much the concerns of this Committee and its terms of reference.

Finally, the Committee believes a national body of this nature-and I refer here to the Australian Children and Families Commission-could serve as an important point of central focus for community organisations and client groups as well as for government and non-government organisations directly involved in the delivery of child and family welfare services. It is becoming increasingly apparent that under existing arrangements the welfare needs of children have been gradually submerged by other competing interest groups seeking assistance from government. It has been estimated that of all children in Australia, a disturbing 15 per cent or approximately 800,000 now live below the poverty line compared with 8 per cent or approximately 250,000 when the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty carried out its inquiry in 1972.

Studies by the Department of Social Security, the Institute of Family Studies and others also reveal that children and their families now represent the new poor in this country and the Institute has pointed out that Australia's expenditure on child care and other family support services is well behind that of countries with which it is often compared-for example, Sweden, France, Germany, Denmark and Israel. The Committee believes that if Australia is to have a sound basis on which to build its future, the growing number of children living in poverty and the long term consequences of this for the nation as a whole must be addressed in a more comprehensive and forward-thinking way than has been the practice in the past. The formation of a statutory authority at the national level is seen as a mechanism through which greater effectiveness and equitability can be achieved in the distribution of the community's resources for child and family welfare purposes.

In making a recommendation for the establishment of an Australian Children and Families Commission, the Committee has stressed that it is not intended that the Commonwealth assume responsibility for the delivery and administration of community services for children and families. Rather, the proposal recognises the need to address child and family welfare problems at the national level and to ensure that, through consultation and co-operation with the States and Territories and the non-governmental organisations, the future provision of services through the present multiplicity of authorities is achieved in a more planned and co-ordinated manner across Australia. In this sense, the body would be similar in purpose to the proposed National Children's Commission for which legislation was passed in 1975 but which was never established.

Before concluding, I endorse Senator Elstob's remarks concerning the degree of co-operation and the level of assistance received by the Committee from all witnesses who gave evidence at the Committee's public hearings, and by others who contributed to the inquiry through written submissions. In particular, I acknowledge with Senator Elstob the contribution made by children to whom we spoke in institutional and other forms of substitute care, their parents or foster parents, and other individuals and representatives.

I also record my appreciation, and that of other members of the Committee, of the assistance and advice received from Ms Monica Darmody whose knowledge and understanding of the problems faced by children in substitute care, her long experience in that field, their carers, as well as those responsible for the administration of substitute care programs, helped clarify many complex issues for the Committee.
Finally, I give my personal thanks and those I am sure of the other Committee members, for the excellent service given us by the Committee Secretary and his very conscientious staff.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare I would like to speak briefly to this report, and together with the other speakers, compliment the Chairman, Senator Elstob, and the Secretary, Chris Shrosbree, and other members of the staff for the good work they have done in the compilation of this report. I guess all honourable senators realise that the very best care that any child can have is that of parents in a good home. We acknowledge that, and as we have been around as members of the Committee we have realised that there are occasions when other care, substitute care, of course is necessary. We know this is brought about by many reasons-sometimes perhaps beyond children's control, where there are parental problems, perhaps where there is divorce or child abuse or family breakdown in many ways. There are reasons why children have to go into institutional care. Even apart from the occasions I have been around with the Committee I have had the opportunity, as I am sure other senators have in the course of their work, of looking at many institutions. We have a very fine institution in Boystown in Queensland. I have had the opportunity to go there on numerous occasions and see the tremendous work that is done for children who are in institutional care there. I certainly am very happy to pay a tribute to the work that is done there.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also the case of foster parents. They have been mentioned on a number of occasions during the debate this evening. There are very many foster parents who give very fond care to the children they look after. I agree with other senators who have spoken this evening and said that they feel that foster parents are not really paid enough to help make up for the care they give at times when children are lacking their own particular parents.

As a signatory to the dissenting report, along with Senator Walters, I want to say that we do not feel that there is the need for the establishment of another Commonwealth statutory authority in this regard. We feel that there are enough Federal departments to look after the problems that have arisen. I was pleased to be able to attend some of the hearings of the Committee and certainly appreciated the tremendous amount of work done by members of the Committee. I appreciate that there are institutional and other forms of care available to children who are badly in need of it when there is a break-up in their homes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my remarks to those of my colleagues on the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare. In particular I would like to thank the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Elstob, for his efforts. I think it should be remarked-and those who know will understand-that Senator Elstob practised remarkable patience in chairing this Committee. I would also like to extend thanks to the secretariat, in particular Chris Shrosbree and the assisting staff. They too portrayed a fair ability at being patient.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very useful report because while it focuses on those children who for one reason or another finish in institutional or other forms of care, it does emphasise not a welfare or problem focus but the needs of all children in our community. That, of course, is why the principal recommendation reads as it does. Senator Bjelke-Petersen made the comment that many of the reasons children finish in institutional or other forms of care are often not their fault. I can almost never think of a case when children are the cause of being removed from home, unless perhaps when they commit some kind of criminal offence; and even then we have to be careful not to see children as the only players.

For the most part, children in institutional or other forms of care are victims. They are victims of the many points listed in the report, including parental neglect, child abuse, homelessness, and parental and family conflict or breakdown, or they are victims because the general family, however we describe it, proves to be improper, unfit or incompetent in providing care for children. For all those reasons and many more, children, the innocent victims in large part of those problems, are removed from the family where the problem exists. They in large part would suffer as a consequence of that removal. Certainly their physical and social welfare may be better attended to, and I am not suggesting in any way that children in institutional or other forms of care are grossly disadvantaged. In fact, we would say that it is mostly the lesser of two evils. Even so in some ways we have, until this point, focused on solving a major problem of society by taking the principal victims and placing them elsewhere. Not only is it inappropriately the focus for solutions to those problems; it is also very costly.

The report's comments and sections devoted to emphasising the importance of the preventive focus in providing services, I am pleased to see, are stressed, and I certainly add my emphasis. I think an emphasis on the need for parental education, for pre-marital and family counselling, for respite care services, particularly for parents with disabled children, for the programs we are now putting in place to deal with child abuse, for economic assistance and counselling, for budget advice, for homemaker services and for much more is a better way to focus on the problems which kids come up with when they are in families which, for one reason or another, are not coping. Of course, we will probably continue to need institutional and other forms of substitute care for quite some time, but it is to be remarked that the number of children in such places has fallen dramatically over the last 10 to 12 years. I think it quite likely that that fall will continue. Hopefully a shift of emphasis to a preventive focus, at least to the same extent as the way in which we address the problem at the moment-by providing care for children-might see a continuing and increased reduction in the number of children who need this type of care.

The principal recommendation addresses the need to establish an Australian Children and Families Commission to advise governments on matters of policy and all such things necessary to develop programs for the welfare of children and families, including strategies, planning and all other things as may be judged necessary. The principal recommendation has the benefit of taking into account the needs of all children in Australia. It will move away from a focus on dealing with only those children who are seen to be problematic, who are in a welfare need, or who are bad children. That is particularly appropriate in this International Year of Youth. I add my voice, as a Government member on this Committee, to support for that principal recommendation, but simply make the comment that the dissenting report suggests that many of the functions suggested in the report and proposed by Government members on the Committee to establish an Australian Children and Families Commission principally are objected to on the grounds of establishing another bureaucracy or statutory authority. The dissenting report says:
Many of these functions are currently being conducted by the Office of Child Care, through the Children's Services Program, and the Institute of Family Studies.

I have no dispute with the fact that those bodies are working very well but, as this report documents also in some considerable detail the inadequacies of our current system, I do not believe that we can rest on the present system. If in fact we judge that the provision of services is inadequate, we then have to judge that the mechanism for dealing with those services, for providing the best care for children in this country, really needs to be reviewed or overhauled too. A commission to act as an umbrella, if you like, to overview and to focus on such places as the Institute of Family Studies and the Office of Child Care seems to me a very useful addition. So it has my support.

There is much in this report that is worth further and more thorough reflection. I will not extend the Senate too much tonight by dwelling on those points. They have been adequately covered by Senator Elstob and Senator Walters. It will be a very useful document for honourable senators to know they have on their shelves. It contains some very useful data and some focusing on the problems of children and of children in care in this country. I commend the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am the first senator to speak on this report who is not a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare. I have not read the report and therefore I will not go into detail. But it is clear on the surface from listening carefully to what has been said by those who have already spoken that this is an important and hallmark report as far as the committee system of this Senate is concerned, that it shows that a great deal of care and attention have been given to it by members of the Committee and that obviously, as Senator Crowley said, it will be a very valuable report for honourable senators to read and take into account.

SPEECH.PARA: There are one or two things that I want to refer to. I listened with care to the statements by a number of speakers this evening. In the first place, Senator Elstob referred, among other things, to the reasons for the investigation as to why children are put into care. He gave as the first reason as family conflict, family breakdown, and so forth. I took it that that was one of the most important reasons why it occurs. It seems to me that that links inevitably with the investigations which the Institute of Family Studies does. It is clear from both sides of the chamber that the works of the Institute of Family Studies were valuable to the Committee in this work. This is clear from the recommendation of the majority report for the setting up of an Australian Children and Families Commission. After detailing the research that should be done the recommendation goes on to say, in connection with the proposed Commission's research function:
The Committee recommends that . . . the Institute of Family Studies be incorporated as the research arm of the Australian Children and Families Commission.

Obviously the Committee has come to the conclusion that the Institute is important and that it should play an increasingly important part in the work which it sees for the proposed Commission. On the other hand, the other members of the Committee who do not think there is a need for a commission place the same obvious value on the Institute of Family Studies. I note that Senator Walters made a particular comment about the value of its work. This is one matter I want to refer to tonight, because it is curiously apposite that at the time this study comes down, the importance of which is fundamental to families in this country, there appears tonight in the Melbourne Herald an article headed `Fund cuts hit family studies' which says:
The Federal Government has sliced the budget of its Melbourne-based Institute of Family Studies by almost a half, according to Institute director, Dr Don Edgar.
Dr Edgar says virtually all research as well as all travelling, lectures, and publishing will have to be halted.
And, he says, the Government's action could be part of a major shake-up involving the Law Reform Commission, the Institute of Criminology and the Human Rights Commission.

I imagine that what is perhaps in mind is the amalgamation in some glorious heap of those four organisations. Consequently, one can imagine that the work done by the proposed combined organisation would be very much less than that done today-not more, as is obviously contemplated. The article goes on:
A review of all four bodies has been ordered which could lead to bringing their research activities into one body.
Dr Edgar says the IFS will insist on a broader public inquiry into the commissions and institutes because `we do not consider this to be an open or representative enough review panel'.
Finally, Dr Edgar is reported to have said:
Apart from salaries, which are fixed costs, our administrative expenses budget item thus takes an effective cut of over 40 per cent in 1985-86 after the upgrade is carried out.

This, I submit to the Senate, is a scandalous situation. It is one that is particularly inappropriate when one considers the importance which is placed upon this body by this report which has been brought down in the Senate tonight. As I understand it, at the moment the Government is conducting a so-called inquiry which is being undertaken by two persons-one from the Attorney-General's Department and one from the Department of Finance. Using someone from the Department of Finance is, if I may use the unfortunate analogy, like putting a child-molester in charge of child-care. It seems to me that it is quite obvious what is intended. There is an intention to cut and slice this body, which has a very good record in the community. It is not as though that body does not want its functions to be analysed. In fact, if one looks at its 1983-84 report one finds that it sets out the way in which it believes amendments should be made to the Act, to set out the various matters which it believes should be functions of the Institute. Although it has sought these things from government for some time, it has not succeeded in getting them. Now at a time when an important report has been presented by the Social Welfare Committee, a report which obviously has involved many hours and weeks of work, one finds that the government is working in the opposite direction. I hope that honourable senators will read this report and take note of this fact. I hope that they will take note of the reports of what is going on in regard to the actual work which the Institute of Family Studies is doing in child-care and other areas. I believe that this is a most unfortunate situation. I raised this matter during debate on this report because I think it is important to draw the attention of the people to the fact that the Government's actions must match its words.

I wish to speak on the report of the Family Law Council entitled `Creating Children'. I believe the Council is to be congratulated on the presentation of this report to the Parliament. I believe that Mr Justice Asche and his committee members are to be commended for undertaking the study of a very significant feature of Australian society which so far has not been subject to such an assessment and a set of proposals which attempt to express an Australian rather than a State, a fragmented or piecemeal view. It is quite clear that the recurring theme of this report is that too often the approach to this wonderful breakthrough in medical technology, which is well-known to all honourable senators, is often spoken of in narrow medical procedure categories and the wider and serious legal, social and ethical issues are not addressed. I believe that this Family Law Council report addresses this issue for the first time, and does so in a very sound and comprehensive manner. The Council speaks, for example, of the fact that this technology is concerned not just with the medical procedure but also with creating a child with family formation. It is therefore said that it is essential that all the interests which are vitally concerned in these matters be represented in any body which proposes the legal, ethical and social framework within which this activity should occur.

The reason that I am taking some time with this matter-I will be only a couple more minutes-is that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs has before it at the moment a reference from this chamber which touches on some of the issues covered in this report. Only this week we are advertising for written submissions and perhaps witnesses on the issue of the legal status of children arising out of in vitro procedures and the need for a national or uniform approach in the way in which the Commonwealth might be able to help. That is only a very narrow aspect. It is well known that in the debate in which the chamber gave us that reference Senator Harradine's Bill was particularly excluded from our purview of this topic.

However, I think this report falls within the general supervisory jurisdiction of this Committee. It may well be that the Senate will find it an advantage to have the Senate Standing Committee look at this report as a whole. That may help the Senate in coming to some conclusions in relation to it. We would be prepared to devote very considerable resources and give some priority to the review of this very important report. That is all I wish to say to indicate to the chamber that my Committee stands ready to aid the chamber in its review of the issues raised by this report. TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the time constraints I will be extremely brief. They are issues of great technological complexity and of considerable complexity so far as jurisprudence is concerned. The committee, of course, did not actually address the latter matter. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the summary of conclusions and recommendations which are attached to that letter and are contained on pages vii to x of the committee's report. In that summary the committee recognised that the questions raised by reproductive technology, which enables the creation of children and the formation of families, are not exclusively or even primarily medical or scientific matters. Rather, they raise fundamental social, moral, legal and ethical issues which involve the whole community.

SPEECH.PARA: It is of considerable concern to me and, I believe, to all members of the Senate who represent the people-the whole of the community-that certain scientists appear to regard these questions as being primarily scientific or medical. Indeed, honourable senators will recall the debate on Huw Evans's show Pressure Point in which Dr Trounson indicated that parliamentary consideration of these questions would be regarded as interference with academic freedom. I also draw attention to the point that was made in Mr Justice Fogarty's letter. The penultimate sentence of Mr Justice Fogarty's letter to the Attorney-General stated:
The Council supports the recommendations which would prohibit the production of human embryos for the sole purpose of research/experimentation or the use of spare human embryos for that purpose . . .

That is a clear indication by a group such as the Family Law Council, with which I do not always agree, that this is a matter of concern to the whole community and ought properly be determined by the representatives of the community-namely, the Parliament. Also in the report concern is raised about reproductive technology being exposed to commercial exploitation. The inference is that it is referring to the Monash University group which has established the company IVF Australia Ltd to market reproductive technology in the United States. One might ask why it would market it in the United States. Why cannot the United States undertake these experiments? As honourable senators would know, the Government of the United States has long since placed a ban on Federal funds for human embryo experimentation. It seems very strange indeed that, on the one hand, scientists can claim that what is being attempted by the Parliament on behalf of the community, for the very minute individuals of our species, is somehow an interference in academic freedom and, on the other hand, can set up a company which will be able to attack that very concept of academic freedom.
